name: Rainwater Harvesting
purpose: To collect and store rainwater for future use, reducing dependence on traditional water sources.
implementation: Rooftop Harvesting: Collecting rainwater from building rooftops and directing it into storage tanks or recharge pits.
Surface Runoff Harvesting: Capturing rainwater from land surfaces and storing it in reservoirs or ponds.
benefits: Provides an alternative water source during dry periods.
notable_example: In India, rainwater harvesting has been practiced for over 4,000 years, serving as a simple process of accumulating and storing rainwater for drinking, irrigation, and livestock use.

name: Johads (Traditional Ponds)
purpose: To capture and store rainwater, primarily for groundwater recharge and agricultural use.
implementation: Constructing small earthen check dams across seasonally flooded gullies to capture rainwater.
benefits: Supports agriculture and drinking water needs.
notable_example: In Rajasthan, organizations like Tarun Bharat Sangh have built over 4,500 johads, leading to the revival of five rivers.

name: Check Dams / Nala Bunds
purpose: To impede water flow in small streams or nalas, facilitating groundwater recharge.
implementation: Constructing small barriers using earth, stones, or concrete across streams to slow water flow and promote percolation.
notable_example: The S M Sehgal Foundation has implemented check dams in Haryana, improving water availability in several villages.

name: Farm Ponds
purpose: To provide on-site water storage for irrigation and other agricultural needs.
implementation: Excavating small ponds on farmland to collect runoff during rains.
benefits: Ensures water availability during dry spells.
notable_example: Farmers in Maharashtra have adopted farm ponds extensively to combat drought conditions.

name: Contour Trenches / Contour Bunding
purpose: To reduce soil erosion and increase water infiltration on sloped lands.
implementation: Digging trenches or building bunds along the natural contours of the land to slow water runoff.
notable_example: In Karnataka, contour bunding has been used to restore degraded lands.

name: Percolation Tanks
purpose: To recharge groundwater by facilitating percolation of stored surface water.
implementation: Constructing shallow tanks in suitable locations to collect runoff, allowing water to percolate into the ground.
benefits: Supports irrigation and drinking water needs.
notable_example: Maharashtra's percolation tanks have significantly improved groundwater availability in rural areas.

name: Recharge Pits & Recharge Wells
purpose: To directly channel rainwater into underground aquifers.
implementation: Constructing pits or wells filled with filtering materials like sand and gravel to allow water to percolate into the ground.
notable_example: Urban areas in Bangalore have adopted recharge wells to combat groundwater depletion.

name: Sand Dams
purpose: To store water in sand-filled reservoirs, reducing evaporation losses.
implementation: Building a reinforced concrete wall across a seasonal riverbed to trap sand, which stores water.
benefits: Provides a reliable water source during dry seasons.
Reduces evaporation compared to open water storage.
notable_example: Sand dams in Kenya have transformed arid regions by providing year-round water.
